ProtocolNumber.description: Unique identifier assigned to the protocol by the sponsor for tracking and regulatory reference. Commonly labeled as 'Protocol No.', 'Protocol Number', or 'Study ID' and found on the cover page, headers, or footers next to the study title and sponsor name. May also appear in an administrative or 'Study Summary' section. Extract the full identifier including letters, numbers, and punctuation (for example, 'ABC-1234-001').

ProtocolTitle.description: Full, official title of the clinical trial protocol as written on the cover page or in the study synopsis. Typically appears near the sponsor name and protocol number and may be labeled as 'Protocol Title', 'Full Title', 'Official Title', or 'Study Title'. Extract the complete title text, not an abbreviation.

StudyTitle.description: Primary study title as it appears in protocol headers, footers, synopsis, or metadata sections. Often matches the protocol title, or may be a shortened or formatted version labeled as 'Study Title', 'Short Title', or 'Abbreviated Title'. Extract the main title used to identify the study throughout the document, even if it differs slightly from the cover-page title.

ClinicalTrialsGovId.description: Registration identifier assigned by ClinicalTrials.gov for the study. Commonly labeled as 'ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier', 'NCT Number', or 'Registry ID' and often appears in the synopsis, administrative, or registry information sections. Format is typically 'NCT' followed by 8 digits (for example, 'NCT01234567'). Extract the full NCT identifier.

DocumentVersionDate.description: Date of the current protocol version, indicating when this version was finalized, approved, or amended. Usually appears on the cover page or in the document header near the protocol number and version (for example, 'Version 3.0, 15 March 2024'). May be labeled as 'Version Date', 'Protocol Date', or 'Effective Date'. Extract the date associated with the active protocol version, not planned or historical dates.

AmendmentNumber.description: Identifier of the current protocol amendment, if applicable. Typically appears on the cover page or in the document header near the protocol number, version, or version date. May be labeled as 'Amendment No.', 'Amendment Number', 'Protocol Amendment', 'Substantial Amendment', or appear as part of a version reference such as 'Version 3.0 (Amendment 2)'. Extract only the amendment identifier (for example, 'Amendment 2' or 'Amendment 02'), not surrounding version text. If no amendment is specified, leave blank.

AmendmentDate.description: Date on which the current protocol amendment was issued, finalized, or approved. Typically appears on the cover page, title page, or document header near the amendment number or version number. May be labeled as 'Amendment Date', 'Date of Amendment', 'Effective Date', or presented alongside text such as 'Amendment 2 – 15 March 2024'. Extract only the amendment's date, not protocol version dates or historical amendment dates.

SponsorName.description: Legal or corporate name of the organization serving as the study sponsor. Typically appears on the cover page, 'Sponsor Information' section, synopsis, or document header and may be labeled as 'Sponsor', 'Study Sponsor', or 'Sponsor/Company'. Extract the full sponsor name (for example, 'Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center' or a pharmaceutical company name) without including addresses or contact details.

StudyPhase.description: Phase of clinical development represented by the study, such as Phase I, Phase II, Phase III, or Phase IV, including combined phases (for example, 'Phase 1/2'). Typically appears on the cover page, synopsis, or in the 'Study Design' or 'Study Overview' sections and may be labeled as 'Study Phase', 'Phase of Development', or 'Clinical Phase'. Extract the phase description exactly as written.

StudyDesign.description: Narrative description of the overall study design, including elements such as randomization, blinding, control groups, number of arms, and major design features. Typically located in the 'Study Design', 'Study Overview', or 'Synopsis' sections and may be labeled as 'Study Design', 'Design Overview', or 'Design Summary'. Extract the paragraph or section that explains how the study is structured rather than detailed procedures or schedules.

StudyPopulationDescription.description: High-level narrative describing the target participant population for the study. Often found in the 'Study Population', 'Study Overview', 'Synopsis', or 'Background and Rationale' sections. May be labeled as 'Target Population', 'Study Population', or 'Patient Population'. Extract the text that summarizes key characteristics such as disease or condition, age group, and other defining features of the participants.

AgeEligibility.description: Description of the age range and sex eligibility of participants allowed to enroll in the study. Typically found in the 'Eligibility Criteria', 'Key Inclusion Criteria', or 'Study Population' sections, and may be labeled as 'Age Range', 'Age Limits', or 'Age and Sex Eligibility'. Extract the statement that describes minimum and/or maximum age (for example, 'Adults ≥18 years') and, when present, the permitted sexes (for example, 'Male and Female').

TotalParticipantCount.description: Total number of participants planned for enrollment in the study across all sites and arms. Commonly labeled as 'Planned Enrollment', 'Target Sample Size', 'Total Number of Subjects', or 'Number of Participants'. Typically appears in the synopsis, 'Study Design', or 'Sample Size' sections. Extract the numeric value representing the overall planned enrollment, not per-site or per-arm counts.

PrimaryObjectives.description: Text describing the main goals of the study, usually focusing on efficacy, safety, or tolerability of the investigational product. Commonly found in the 'Objectives and Endpoints', 'Study Objectives', or 'Synopsis' sections under a heading such as 'Primary Objective' or 'Primary Objectives'. Extract the statement(s) that specify what the study is primarily designed to evaluate, not secondary or exploratory objectives.

PrimaryEndpoints.description: Description of the primary outcome measures used to assess the primary objectives of the study. Typically located in the 'Objectives and Endpoints', 'Outcome Measures', or 'Efficacy/Safety Endpoints' sections under a heading such as 'Primary Endpoints' or 'Primary Efficacy Endpoints'. Extract the complete definition of the primary endpoints, including the variable being measured, method of assessment, and timepoints when available.

InclusionCriteria.description: Block of text listing the conditions that must be met for a participant to be eligible for the study. Usually appears in the 'Eligibility Criteria' section under a heading such as 'Inclusion Criteria', 'Key Inclusion Criteria', or 'Main Inclusion Criteria'. Often formatted as a numbered or bulleted list. Extract the full inclusion criteria text, preserving its list structure where possible.

ExclusionCriteria.description: Block of text listing the conditions that disqualify a participant from enrolling in the study. Typically found in the 'Eligibility Criteria' section under a heading such as 'Exclusion Criteria', 'Key Exclusion Criteria', or 'Main Exclusion Criteria', often following the inclusion criteria. Usually presented as a numbered or bulleted list. Extract the full exclusion criteria text, preserving its list structure where possible.

ArmTitle.description: Name or label of the study arm, treatment group, or cohort. Usually found in the 'Study Design', 'Treatment Arms', 'Interventions', or 'Study Groups' sections and may be labeled as 'Arm', 'Cohort', 'Group', or 'Treatment Regimen'. Examples include 'Arm A: Investigational Drug + Standard of Care' or 'Placebo Control Arm'. Extract the full title of each arm.

ArmDescription.description: Detailed description of the interventions, dosing regimen, and key characteristics for the corresponding study arm. Typically appears under arm-specific headings in the 'Study Design', 'Treatment Plan', or 'Interventions' sections. May include drug name(s), dose, route of administration, frequency, treatment duration, and comparator details. Extract the full descriptive text associated with each arm.

StudyArms.description: Collection of all study arms, cohorts, or treatment groups defined in the protocol. Each item includes an arm title and arm description as specified in the 'Study Design', 'Treatment Arms', or 'Interventions' sections. Extract one entry per distinct arm or cohort.

cohort_module_name.description: Identifier for the cohort, module, appendix, treatment arm, or population to which this assessment schedule belongs. Typically found in table headers, section titles, or column labels in modular protocol designs. May be labeled as 'Cohort', 'Module', 'Appendix', 'Arm', 'Treatment Group', or 'Study Population'. Common examples include 'Core Protocol', 'Arm A', or 'Cohort 1'. For single-cohort or non-modular studies where all assessments apply universally, use 'General' or 'Core Protocol'. Generate the specific identifier that distinguishes this visit schedule from others in the document based on nearby headings and labels.

visit_identifier.description: Name, label, or number identifying the specific visit or timepoint. Typically appears in the first column or row header of schedule tables and may be labeled as 'Visit', 'Visit Number', 'Timepoint', 'Study Day', or 'Cycle/Visit'. Common formats include 'Visit 1', 'Screening', 'Baseline', 'Cycle 2 Day 1', 'End of Treatment', 'Follow-up Visit 1', or 'Week 4'. Extract the exact visit identifier as it appears in the schedule table, including any prefixes, suffixes, or numbering schemes used in the document.

visit_timing.description: Specific timing, schedule window, or relative time frame for when the visit occurs. Typically found in schedule tables under columns labeled as 'Timing', 'Schedule', 'Window', 'Study Day', 'Days', or 'Timeframe'. May be expressed as absolute days (for example, 'Day 1', 'Day 28'), relative windows (for example, 'Days -28 to 0', 'Days 1–7'), or event-based timing (for example, 'Within 7 days of progression', 'Prior to first dose', 'At screening'). Extract the complete timing specification including any ranges, windows, or conditional timing statements that define when the visit should occur.

procedure_name.description: Short label (approximately 3–15 words) summarizing the clinical procedure, test, assessment, or activity being performed. Extract the procedure name as it appears in the document, typically found in schedule table rows or columns. May be labeled with standard clinical trial terminology. Common examples include 'Informed consent', 'Randomization in IRT', 'Urine pregnancy test', 'Vital signs', 'Immunogenicity blood draw', 'Medical history', 'Physical examination', 'ECG', 'Tumor assessment', 'CT scan', 'Adverse event assessment', 'Concomitant medications', or 'Study drug administration'. Extract the procedure name as written in the document without including full instructions, rationale, or multi-sentence descriptions; keep those details in conditional_notes.

conditional_notes.description: Full contextual instructions, conditions, and narrative descriptions associated with this procedure. Extract complete text including timing specifications (for example, 'on Day 1 prior to vaccination', 'within 2 hours of administration'), triggers or conditions (for example, 'if temperature ≥39°C', 'if clinically indicated', 'at investigator discretion'), patient subpopulations (for example, 'only for WOCBP', 'for participants with measurable disease'), sample collection details (for example, 'collect 20 mL', 'fasting required'), frequency specifications (for example, 'every 2 cycles', 'at progression only'), and cross-references (for example, 'see Section 8.3.4'). Typically found in table footnotes, superscript symbol legends (for example, *, †, ‡), parenthetical text, or dedicated 'Notes' columns adjacent to the schedule table. Multi-sentence text is acceptable. Extract all conditional notes, footnotes, and special instructions that modify when, how, or for whom the procedure should be performed.

category.description: Classification of the procedure type based on its primary purpose and the data it generates. Use one of: Administrative, Safety, Laboratory, Efficacy, Imaging, PK/PD, or Other. Infer from context and procedure name. Administrative procedures include study management activities such as 'Informed consent', 'Randomization in IRT', 'Study drug dispensing', 'Visit scheduling', or 'Source documentation'. Safety procedures monitor patient safety such as 'Record AEs', 'Vital signs', 'Physical examination', 'ECG', or 'Adverse event assessment'. Laboratory procedures include sample collection and analysis such as 'blood sample for immunogenicity', 'Hematology', 'Chemistry', 'Serology', 'Urine pregnancy test', or 'Biomarker analysis'. Efficacy procedures measure treatment effectiveness such as 'Tumor assessment', 'Response evaluation', or 'Disease progression assessment'. Imaging procedures include diagnostic imaging such as 'CT scan', 'MRI', 'PET scan', or 'X-ray'. PK/PD procedures relate to pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics such as 'PK sampling', 'Pharmacokinetic analysis', or 'PD markers'. Use 'Other' for procedures that do not clearly fit the above categories.

procedures_list.description: Complete list of all medical procedures, assessments, evaluations, or activities scheduled to occur at this specific visit or timepoint. Typically found in schedule tables where each row represents a procedure and columns indicate which visits include that procedure, or where each column represents a visit and rows list the procedures. May also be supplemented by narrative visit descriptions or footnotes that clarify additional procedures or conditions. Extract all procedures, tests, assessments, and activities that are scheduled for this visit, including those indicated by checkmarks, symbols, or other markers in the table.

items.description: Single visit entry representing one distinct visit, timepoint, or visit window in the assessment schedule. Contains the cohort or module identifier that groups this visit, the visit identifier and timing information, and a complete list of all procedures, assessments, and activities scheduled for that visit along with any conditional notes or special instructions associated with each procedure.

ScheduleOfAssessments.description: Structured, visit-by-visit breakdown of all assessments, procedures, and evaluations scheduled throughout the clinical trial. Typically found in sections labeled as 'Schedule of Assessments', 'Schedule of Activities', 'Study Procedures Schedule', 'Visit Schedule', 'Time and Events Schedule', or 'Study Calendar'. May appear as a comprehensive table in the main protocol body, in dedicated appendix sections, or as modular schedules for different cohorts or treatment arms. Each array item represents a distinct visit, visit window, or timepoint where assessments occur. Extract all visits from both standard protocol tables and any modular or fragmented appendix sections that contain assessment schedules.
